facts.text: An arbitration agreement had been filed in court under s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, and an order of reference made thereon.
The arbitrator entered upon the reference and made and filed his award in court on July 14, 1955.
The award concerned partition of certain properties between the wife and children of one Bhairon Bux.
The award was unstamped and unregistered.
Objection taken to a judgment being passed on such an award.
Trial court passed an order remitting the award to the arbitrator for re-submitting it to the court on a duly stamped paper and after getting it registered.
Against this order, revision filed in Madhya Pradesh High Court at Nagpur in Civil Revision No. 966 of 1955.
High Court Single Judge took view that award required stamping but could not be remitted under s.16; referred three questions to larger bench based on earlier judgment in Ramkumar v. Kushalchand.

Questions referred: (1) Is award under s.20 chargeable to stamp duty? (2) Compulsorily registerable for partition of immovable property value Rs.100+? (3) Court power under s.16(1)(c) or otherwise to remit for stamping/registration?

Division Bench: Parties agreed award needs stamping (disposed first question); did not answer second; answered third in affirmative under s.16(1)(c) as illegality apparent on face; followed Lakhmichand v. Kalloolal and approved Ramkumar v. Kushalchand. Judgment dated July 26, 1957.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Court has powers under section 16(1)(c) of the Arbitration Act of 1940 or otherwise to remit an award to the arbitrator or umpire to get it stamped and/or registered?
Is the award made on a reference by the Court on an application under section 20 of the Arbitration Act chargeable to stamp duty?
Is such an award compulsorily registerable when it relates to partition of immovable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards?

petitioner_arguments.text: Remission under s.16(1)(c) is only for reconsideration of merits, not for re-writing on stamped paper; want of stamp is defect dehors the award, like want of registration.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arbitration Act s.16(1)(c); Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha

respondent_arguments.text: Award requires stamping; can be remitted under s.16(1)(c) as illegality apparent on face; copying on stamped paper is ministerial; arbitrator not functus officio for this.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Arbitration Act s.16(1)(c), s.14(1); Lakhmichand v. Kalloolal; Ramkumar v. Kushalchand; CPC s.151

respondent_arguments.text: Under s.14(1), arbitrator duty to inform of fees/charges including stamp; supports order.
Inherent powers under CPC s.151 via Arbitration Act s.41.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.16(1)(c), remission only for reconsideration of merits; re-writing on stamped paper is not reconsideration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reconsideration imports fresh consideration of matters referred; nothing reconsidered in re-writing.

court_reasoning.text: Want of stamp is defect dehors the award, like want of registration; not covered by s.16(1)(c).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quotes Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha.

court_reasoning.text: S.14(1) only requires informing of fees/charges; does not justify re-inscribing on stamped paper; doubts if 'charges' include stamp duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stamping at execution per Stamp Act s.17; post-execution info only.

court_reasoning.text: Arbitrator functus officio after award; CPC s.151 cannot empower fresh award.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quotes Mordue v. Palmer; Russel on Arbitration.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.13(d),15(b),(c) not applicable: no clerical mistake; court did not exercise modification power.

holdings.text: Division Bench erred; award cannot be remitted under s.16(1)(c) to re-write on stamped paper.

precedents_cited.treatment: approved by High Court, but implicitly doubted
precedents_cited.relevance: Held unstamped award remittable under CPC Sch I para 14 (reproduced in s.16)
Copying award on stamped paper is ministerial; arbitrator retains authority

precedents_cited.case_name: Nani Bala Saha v. Ram Gopal Saha
precedents_cited.relevance: S.16(1)(c) only for error of law on face; want of registration/stamp dehors award
Arbitrator functus officio after signing award

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs filing, remission, notice of fees, inherent powers via CPC, correction/modification of awards

statutes_cited.name: Indian Stamp Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Stamping required at time of execution

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Remission for unstamped award; inherent powers applicable via Arbitration Act s.41

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of courts below remitting the award set aside; appellant gets costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "Under s. 16 of the Arbitration Act an award can be remitted to the arbitrators only for reconsideration. When it is remitted for re-writing it on a stamped paper, it is not remitted for reconsideration."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing ministerial act from reconsideration

key_quotes.text: "That cl.(c) means this and nothing more namely, that where the court finds an error of law in the award itself... it can remit the award to the arbitrator for reconsideration."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Nani Bala defining scope of s.16(1)(c)

key_quotes.text: "after making his award the arbitrator is functus officio."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why court cannot direct fresh copy as award
